p: Altogether, 28 accessions were evaluated, 15 belonging to MOFF ( M1, M2, M4–M8, M10, M11, M13, M16, M25–M27, M29) and 13 to MALT ( M9, M12, M14, M15, M17–M24, M28). Accession M3 had to be excluded from the study as no plant material was available. The variability of simple morphological traits as shoot development and leaf sizes has been recorded in the second year of growth and both subspecies were compared as presented in Table 1. Significant differences were found for the characters shoot length ( p = 0.002), distance of nodes ( p < 0.001) and the ratio leaf length/width ( p = 0.015). Thus, on average plants of MALT had longer shoots and spaces between nodes but a lower leaf length to width ratio, and their leaves appeared more orbicular.
